newsitem.title: CHINA: China not a military threat - Beijing.
newsitem.headline: China not a military threat - Beijing.

text.p: China's defense minister, Chi Haotian, on Thursday said the idea of a militarily aggressive China was "sheer nonsense," and that he saw dialogue with the United States as essential for regional peace.

"The maintenance of friendly relations between China and the U.S. is of significance not only for the Asia-Pacific region but the whole world," China's official Xinhua news agency quoted Chi as saying.
Chi told Admiral Joseph Prueher, commander of the U.S. Pacific Command, in a meeting in Beijing that the theories of a "China threat" were "sheer nonsense," Xinhua said.
"Contact is better than containment, and dialogue is better than confrontation," Chi said. In Cold War parlance, "containment" meant restricting the spread of communism.

Chi, who has been invited to visit the United States, said he hoped a recent warming of Sino-U.S. relations would continue and that the issue of Taiwan would be the focal point of ties between Washington and Beijing.
Relations between the two Pacific giants plunged in March when China conducted missile tests off the coast of Taiwan in the run-up to the island's first direct presidential elections.
Washington responded by sending two aircraft carrier battle groups to the region in a show of support for Taiwan.
Beijing has regarded Taiwan as a rebel province since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949, and has sought to push the island into diplomatic isolation.
Prueher said the United States did not see China as a threat and that prosperity in China was in the interests of Washington.
